key_channel_insights.line_content: Fare parity remains high at 97.4%, but a 75% week-over-week spike in missing OTA offers (now 1.9%) signals an urgent distribution issue rather than a pricing problem.
60% of metasearch itineraries undercut the website (-0.13% average), creating broad but shallow leakage; encouragingly, parity is up 7 ppt month-over-month.
GDS holds 97.9% parity, yet ‘GDS Higher’ cases on long-haul surged 177% week-over-week—small in volume (0.81%) but concentrated in close-in bookings.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: Website-to-OTA fare parity held at 97.4% of itineraries, keeping overall channel risk low.
Missing OTA offers jumped to 1.9% of searches—up 75% week-over-week—indicating a rapid availability gap.
Parity drops to 88.9% on long-haul routes, with 3.5% priced higher on OTA, elevating customer-cost and brand-perception risk.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 1.9% of itineraries lacked an OTA offer, a 75% week-over-week surge and 15% above last month.
Exact-match fares slipped 0.9 ppt to 97.4%, still industry-leading but declining for a second straight period.
0.8% of itineraries were costlier on OTA (avg. +0.18%), frequency up 16% week-over-week.
Discounting against the website is virtually absent (<0.1%) and continues to decline.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: Parity at 98.2%; missing offers rose to 1.3% (+83% WoW) but higher-priced instances remain rare (0.5%).
Parity falls to 88.9%, with 7.6% unavailable and 3.5% higher-priced on OTA (avg. +0.22%).

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: For U.S. departures: 97.4% parity, 1.9% missing, 0.75% higher-priced—no geo-specific anomaly.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Inside 14 days, 2.6% of fares were missing (+118% WoW) and 0.9% higher-priced; parity at 96.5% but declining fastest here.
Beyond 30 days, parity peaks at 99.3%; missing offers drop to 0.3%, though OTA premiums re-emerged at 0.3%.

mse_highlights.line_content: Metasearch lists lower fares on 60% of itineraries (avg. ‑0.13%), indicating broad revenue leakage.
Price-match share rose 7 ppt month-over-month to 38%, led by gains in the close-in window.
88% of long-haul journeys are underpriced with a deeper ‑0.20% gap and zero ‘higher-than-site’ cases.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Only 0.5% of searches lacked a website fare on MSE, down 0.05 ppt WoW.
Identical fares now at 38%, up 2.8 ppt WoW and 7.0 ppt MoM—the fastest improvement across channels.
Still 60% lower pricing, but incidence down 1.7 ppt WoW and 6.2 ppt MoM; discount unchanged at ‑0.13%.
Premium pricing only 1% of cases, declining 1.1 ppt WoW with a modest +0.10% markup.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: Underpricing affects 58% of ODs (-0.12%), improving 6.6 ppt MoM as parity climbs to 42%.
88% lower pricing and no parity on long-haul; deepest discount at ‑0.20%.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Home-market mirrors global view: 60% lower, 38% same, 1% higher.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Within 15 days, lower fares drop to 59% (-9 ppt MoM) as parity reaches 40%.
15+ days out: 63% lower pricing (-0.08% gap) and a 100% WoW spike in ‘higher’ cases—monitor beyond near term.

gds_highlights.line_content: GDS matched the website on 97.9% of itineraries, keeping leakage risk low.
Long-haul shows a 4.1% ‘GDS Higher’ rate—eight times short-haul—and up 177% WoW.
87% of all higher-than-website fares occur in the 0-14-day window.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 1.24% of searches lacked a GDS fare, up 11% WoW—early sign of content gaps.
97.9% of itineraries priced identically; flat MoM and down just 0.3 ppt WoW.
0.81% of itineraries priced above web (+16% WoW); avg. premium +0.17%.
Only 0.05% discounting with a ‑0.14% markdown; no material trend.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: Parity at 97.9%; ‘GDS Higher’ contained at 0.81%—no regional divergence.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: All monitored traffic originates in the US; metrics align with overall performance.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 15+ days: parity 99.3%; only 0.33% priced higher—no deterioration observed.
